Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Modeling and Visualization of Latent Communities

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: In many areas of human professional and social life, people tend to form more or less clearly defined communities. The main problem of these hidden or latent communities is that they are really hard to discover since the borders of these communities cut through various professional and organizational borders. The modern social Web, however, provides a huge volume of alternative data sources for discovering latent communities. The goal of this proposal is to explore a range of promising approaches that can be used to elicit latent communities from various kinds of data about individuals available in the modern social Web and deliver the results for human thinking and interactive exploration through interactive visualizations. The visualization provided will allow humans explore and manipulate the results delivered by the new algorithms. This will deliver results that are produced by the joint power of human and artificial intelligence. In the course of the project, the team will build several data sets combining data of several social Web systems and use these data sets to develop, evaluate, and compare several elicitation and visualization approaches. The work will advance the research on latent communities, community and user modeling, and interactive social visualization. At the same time, the work will constitute one of the first attempts to use a variety of social Web data and a variety of approaches for community modeling. To increase the broader impact of the project, the researcher will apply the latent community knowledge to several practical tasks, such as identifying proper academic mentors and forming coherent collaboration groups. They will also engage a number of students in the research advancing their training into this emerging field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to explore a range of promising approaches to elicit and visualize latent communities from various kinds of data about individuals available on the modern Social Web. While the problem of community discovery and visualization has been relatively well explored in the past, the Social Web introduced a number of challenges not addressed in the previous research. Most importantly, prior research mostly explored social data based on a single type of connection between users such as e-mail contacts, co-authorship, or communication in discussion forums. The increase of information available on the Web and, specifically data available in social systems, makes it possible to discover various kinds of connections and various dimensions of similarity between users. This data provides evidence about multiple types of latent groups and sub-communities existing in the larger user community. New approaches are required to reliably find and visualize these ill-defined, frequently overlapping groups.

Understanding the inherently noisy nature of social Web data, we approached the problem of community discovery and modeling as a human-computer collaboration problem. In this context, the community discovery and intelligent clustering algorithms are not expected to produce definitive answers. Instead, their goal is provide data for human thinking and interactive exploration. The communication between the computer and human intelligence is performed through interactive visualizations. Using this visualization, humans should be able to explore and manipulate the results delivered by the algorithms. In turn, their manipulations will be utilized by the algorithms to produce results that are informed by both human and artificial intelligence. Our study was designed as two-year project. This report summarizes the results of the first project year that was focused on exploring a range of known community mining approaches and several kinds of innovative interactive visualization approaches. The goal of this stage was to determine to what extent these approaches were appropriate to work with the new noisy multi-dimensional data available in the social systems. The goal of the second year will be to develop new community mining approaches better suited to social data as well as to increase the interactivity level with visualization tools.

We started the first year by building four multi-dimensional datasets combining open data with data from some social Web systems. These datasets were immediately used to explore a broad range of community elicitation approaches. Among the explored approaches were probabilistic propagation approaches (such as affinity propagation and label propagation), graph-based approaches (such as modularity maximization and a generative graph model method) and latent dimensionality reduction approaches. We also experimented with some non-exclusive elicitation approaches that produce overlapping communities and some multidimensional approaches that distinguish between different dimensions of similarity (such as principal modularity maximization). To visualize the results of community mining, we developed and evaluated several innovative interactive in-browser visualization approaches based on Java applets, JavaScript and Flash frameworks. The majority of these approaches use exclusive clustering and traditional node-link visualization metaphors coupled with several kinds of interactivity – the ability to move and explore nodes, expand and collapse clusters, move nodes and clusters using PoIs (Points of Interest), and explore community development timelines. We also experimented with two approaches to visualize overlapping communities – one based on node-link with multi-colored nodes and another based on VIBE relevance visualization.
